channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: One dead, many hurt in M5 crash
item.description: One person dies and 39 others are injured in a crash involving a coach and a lorry on the M5 in the West Midlands.

item.title: Concern over nursery staff skills
item.description: A review of the qualifications for nursery staff and childminders has highlighted concerns about literacy and numeracy skills among workers.

item.title: ISS alert over passing space junk
item.description: The crew of the International Space Station (ISS) briefly took refuge in escape capsules over fears that satellite debris could strike it.

item.title: Egypt football ban sparks clashes
item.description: New deadly clashes erupt in Egypt's Port Said, after the Egyptian city's football team is suspended over fatal match violence in February.

item.title: Bolton plan Muamba mosaic tribute
item.description: A large mosaic spelling out the name and shirt number of Fabrice Muamba will be displayed by Bolton fans ahead of the team's home game against Blackburn.

item.title: Food firms to aid calorie battle
item.description: Seventeen major food and drink companies firms promise to cut calories in their products to help tackle obesity.

item.title: Shot ex-banker under armed guard
item.description: Russian former banker German Gorbuntsov is under armed guard in hospital after being shot several times by a man in east London.

item.title: Stamp duty holiday comes to end
item.description: The stamp duty holiday for first-time house buyers has ended, meaning they will join others in paying 1% tax on properties worth more than £125,000.

item.title: Six charged over child sex trade
item.description: Six men are charged in connection with an investigation into child exploitation in Oxford, following a series of raids on properties in the city.

item.title: Mexico crowds cheer Pope Benedict
item.description: Thousands of supporters greet Pope Benedict XVI on his first visit to Mexico, as he denounces the "evil" of drug-related violence in the country.

item.title: Call to regulate comparison sites
item.description: Price comparison websites should be regulated because the information they provide is not always fair, a consumer group says.

item.title: Australia extinction 'due to man'
item.description: Human hunters were responsible for the extinction of Australia's giant vertebrates about 40,000 years ago, scientists conclude.

item.title: Sport Relief raises record £50m
item.description: Sport Relief has raised £50m in public donations, a new on-the-night record for the charity telethon.

item.title: Queen surprise 'guest' at wedding
item.description: The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh pose for wedding pictures with a newlywed couple during a Jubilee visit to Manchester.

item.title: Surprise US World Bank candidate
item.description: President Obama nominates Korean-born US academic Jim Yong Kim as his surprise choice to head the World Bank, as two other candidates are named.

item.title: EMI in Europe competition probe
item.description: The European Commission launches a probe into whether the sale of UK music firm EMI - home to the Beatles, Pink Floyd and Coldplay - breaks competition rules.

item.title: 'No compromises' in Union battle
item.description: Scottish Conservatives are urged to offer "no compromises" to the SNP in their battle to keep the Union.

item.title: Minimum price for alcohol planned
item.description: The government proposes a minimum price of about 40p per unit of alcohol in England and Wales - but is warned it could face a legal challenge.

item.title: Abortion clinics get spot-checks
item.description: Inspectors have been ordered into abortion clinics across England to carry out spot-checks on how they work.

item.title: Warning over co-codamol tablets
item.description: The UK medicines regulator has issued a warning after the wrong strength of tablets was put into some packets of the painkiller co-codamol.

item.title: Free schools 'are waste of money'
item.description: Opening free schools in parts of England where they are not needed is a "shameful" waste of taxpayers' money, the leader of a head teachers' union has said.

item.title: Schools 'required to fill vacuum'
item.description: Schools are 'too often asked to make up for much wider failings within families and communities', Ofsted chief inspector says.

item.title: Cashing in on online Ponzi scams
item.description: Investors are using web-based tracker tools to put their money into online scams in the hope of cashing out before the schemes collapse, research suggests.

item.title: Spies 'penetrate' US army network
item.description: Foreign spies have comprehensively penetrated the computer networks of the US government, American politicians have been told.

item.title: Solar tariff loss for government
item.description: The government fails to get permission to appeal to the Supreme Court over its plan to cut subsidies for solar panels on homes.

item.title: Giant asteroid 'resembles planet'
item.description: The giant asteroid Vesta has many features that are usually associated with rocky planets like Earth, according to data from a Nasa probe.

item.title: Music festivals show rapid growth
item.description: Figures from the music industry indicate that earnings from Scotland's music festivals have almost trebled in the past six years.

item.title: Mozart piece uncovered in Austria
item.description: A previously unknown piano composition by Mozart, believed to have been written when he was as young as 10, is uncovered in Austria.

item.title: The chia craze
item.description: Many people in the UK won't have heard of the chia seed, but if regulators give their backing this US superfood craze could be on the way.

item.title: Are thin women the enemy?
item.description: From super-skinny celebrities to models with low BMI, people are speaking out about women they perceive to be too thin. But some experts worry this behaviour makes things worse.

item.title: Broad sits out England training
item.description: England bowler Stuart Broad sits out training with an ankle strain ahead of Monday's first Test against Sri Lanka.

item.title: Watson is a 'fighter' - Azarenka
item.description: World number one Victoria Azarenka is looking forward to taking on British teenager Heather Watson at the Miami Masters.

item.title: Hamilton on pole ahead of Button
item.description: McLaren's Lewis Hamilton is on pole for the Malaysian GP, with Jenson Button second and Michael Schumacher third.

item.title: Coach Hanks departs Sale Sharks
item.description: Sale announces the departure of first-team coach Tony Hanks in the wake of Friday's heavy 9-45 defeat to Saracens.

item.title: Police to track A&E injury data
item.description: The scale of knife and gun crime in London is set to be tracked by police using pooled data from hospital A&E units.

item.title: Fraudsters must pay back £1 each
item.description: Two fraudsters who conned investors out of more than £3m in a property scam must pay back £1 each after they lost the cash gambling.

item.title: Man held in 'firearms incident'
item.description: A 37-year-old man is arrested following what police are describing as a "firearms incident" in Falkirk.

item.title: Metal thieves 'threaten heritage'
item.description: Metal theft could be causing "irreparable" damage to Scotland's heritage, a BBC Scotland investigation finds.

item.title: Two charged over couple's murder
item.description: Two men are charged with the murders of a husband and wife in Craigavon last year.

item.title: Belfast airport pulls runway plan
item.description: The management of Belfast City Airport withdraw their plans to extend the runway at the east Belfast site.

item.title: Plaid 'aiming to hold its ground'
item.description: May's local elections cannot be seen as a referendum on new Plaid Cymru leader Leanne Wood, insists the party chair.

item.title: Students cut off by tide rescued
item.description: Two students are treated for suspected hypothermia after being rescued by lifeboat crews when they were cut off by the tide at Aberystwyth.

item.title: African force set up to hunt Kony
item.description: A military force set up by the African Union to track down notorious Ugandan warlord Joseph Kony is being launched in South Sudan.

item.title: EU approves pirate base attacks
item.description: The European Union expands its mission against Somali pirates, by allowing military forces to attack land targets as well as those at sea.

item.title: Japan prepares missile defences
item.description: Japan orders missile defence systems to be prepared in response to the planned launch of a North Korean long-range rocket next month.

item.title: S Lanka minister in media threat
item.description: A Sri Lankan cabinet minister threatens violence against journalists and human rights activists who he says have been opposing the government.

item.title: French teacher 'in Merah tribute'
item.description: A teacher in France is suspended over claims she asked pupils to hold a minute's silence for gunman Mohamed Merah, reports say.

item.title: Breivik spurs health law revision
item.description: Norway plans new mental health laws to cater for mass killer Anders Behring Breivik's detention, as his trial looms.

item.title: Brazil police hunt 'blonde gang'
item.description: Brazilian police say they are hunting a gang of blonde young women blamed for a string of kidnaps and robberies.

item.title: Guatemala arrests ex-police chief
item.description: Guatemala arrests former police chief Marlene Blanco Lapola for alleged involvement in extra-judicial killings of criminal suspects.

item.title: EU slaps sanctions on Assad wife
item.description: The EU imposes a travel ban and an asset freeze on Asma al-Assad, the British-born wife of Syrian leader Bashar, and other family members.

item.title: US aid to Palestinians released
item.description: US lawmakers release $88.6m (£56m) in development aid for the Palestinians that has been frozen for more than six months.

item.title: Obama's sorrow for shot teenager
item.description: President Obama says the "tragedy" of a black teenager killed by a neighbourhood watchman in Florida should prompt national soul-searching.

item.title: Bales charged with Afghan murders
item.description: Robert Bales, the US soldier suspected of killing Afghan civilians, has been charged with 17 counts of premeditated murder, the US Army says.

item.title: In pictures: Childhood tuberculosis in Lima
item.description: Young people fighting tuberculosis in Peru

item.title: Day in pictures: 23 March 2012
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 23 March

item.title: In pictures: Team GB Olympic kits from the past
item.description: Team GB past and present

item.title: Your pictures: Cooking
item.description: On the theme of cooking

item.title: Day in pictures: 22 March 2012
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 22 March 2012

item.title: In pictures: Russian Empire in colour photos
item.description: Rarely seen colour photos

item.title: In pictures: Judith Tebbutt freed by kidnappers
item.description: Judith Tebbutt released by kidnappers

item.title: In pictures: Police raid in Toulouse
item.description: Armed police in the French city of Toulouse

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: Home Secretary Theresa May has announced that the government will introduce a minimum price for alcohol.

item.title: VIDEO: Inside the Toulouse gunman's flat
item.description: Video footage has been released showing the inside of the Toulouse apartment of Mohamed Merah, the man who shot dead 7 people.

item.title: VIDEO: Sport Relief raises on-the-night record
item.description: Sport Relief has raised £50m in public donations, a new on-the-night record for the charity telethon.

item.title: VIDEO: Explorer's lifeboat journey recreated
item.description: Almost 100 years ago polar explorer Sir Ernest Shackleton set out to cross the Antarctic and failed.

item.title: VIDEO: Obama: Trayvon death 'a tragedy'
item.description: As an investigation gets under way into the shooting of an unarmed black teenager in Florida, the US President was asked to comment on the case.

item.title: VIDEO: Hundreds wrongly told of lottery win
item.description: Three hundred people in Denmark were wrongly told they had won three billion euros in their country's national lottery.

item.title: VIDEO: People take to the UK beaches
item.description: Parts of the UK are basking with temperatures 10C higher than the seasonal average with some people taking to the beach.

item.title: VIDEO: Karachi kidnappings help fund Taliban
item.description: In Pakistan's largest city, Karachi, police say the Taliban are generating funds through bank robberies, protection rackets and kidnappings.

item.title: VIDEO: Obama's surprise World Bank nominee
item.description: Barack Obama has revealed his nomination for the new head of the World Bank. He is a Korean-born American academic called Jim Yong Kim, who has a sideline in musical performance, as John McManus reports.

item.title: VIDEO: Five Minutes With: Christopher Eccleston
item.description: Christopher Eccleston on acting and unfulfilled ambition

item.title: What's it like to be a disabled dad?
item.description: What's it like to be a disabled dad?

item.title: Is a pain-free needle possible?
item.description: The British inventor who says he has invented a pain-free needle

item.title: How I survived a plane crash
item.description: I fell two miles from a plane and survived

item.title: Unification Church faces change
item.description: What does the future hold for the Unification Church?

item.title: The UK firms who tackle Somali pirates
item.description: The UK security firms dominating Somalia's anti-piracy industry

item.title: Week in pictures: 17-23 March 2012
item.description: News photos from around the world this week
